review_title: Starting to see why people keep leaving.
job_title: Telemetry Technician in Green Bay, WI
pros: There is so much to learn, and many of my experienced co-workers go out of their way to teach me, which has been awesome.
cons: I was a bit disappointed we were made to work Christmas eve (was a Saturday- I am normally required to work every 3rd weekend, this being my weekend off; also, my holiday, to work, on the schedule, was New years day), which was our weekend off. So I worked Christmas eve, a 12 hour shift, and only was paid holiday pay from 5 PM to 7PM. I think my Christmas bonus was $10 ( no, not kidding- they give employees "points" as appreciation, and then the points are loaded onto an employee appreciation shopping site. It's like Chucke cheese gifts for adults, and you need over 100000 points for something nice, such as a gemstone sterling silver necklace. I received 2500 or 3000 points in a card in the mail. I was stoked, until I opened the app and literally couldn't get one thing because this amount of points is equivalent to less than $5. Just kind of a slap in the face (and cheap, in my opinion).

review_title: Great place to work until Andy Bagnall became C.E.O.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Eau Claire, WI
pros: All departments are miserable together.
cons: No job security. Andy Bagnall did 3 rounds of furloughs and 3 rounds of lay-offs then made T.V. and radio appearances to tell the public how understaffed we are. The people who volunteered to furlough and were laid off instead of brought back received no unemployment, a fact that HSHS failed to tell people when they asked us to furlough. Unemployment considers this a voluntary exit. Employees are overworked because Andy Bagnall got rid of everyone and is requiring those left to take on other jobs. This hospital is extremely nurse centric. If you are not a nurse you will receive no recognition, you stand very little chance of promotion, and you will not recieve the same benefits. The promises you are made upon hire are quickly broken and if you voice concern you are told that policy states that your responsibilities can change at any time. You must find your own coverage for vacation or you cannot go, this is policy, so you should hope your coworkers will cover you.

So i was stuck in a endless loop of tough scheduling.

review_title: Sad to see what it has become
job_title: in Effingham, IL
pros: The local staff and employees that I worked with at the hospital level were exceptional.
cons: Corporate office has taken over control of hospital practices without any direct knowledge of day to day operations.  Extremely poor management and decision making.  Management is more concerned with posturing than doing what is right for the patient and the employees.  Employees are not valued and workloads unrealistic.  I worked there for more than 10 years and it was sad to see how the changes caused an exodus of very valuable and knowledgeable employees.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Green Bay, WI
pros:
Vactions PTO, PRN flexibility, caring for people.
This company was great when I started over 12 years ago.  Nurses were in high demand and they paid well treated employees with respect and offered great patient care.  Around 5 years ago the hospital changed the way they staff their floors.  The nurses had to take on more patients with less help.  Then a few years after that they cut all of our help at the nurses station (HUC).  Now an RN has to answer the phones while caring for patients.  Even the YMCA has a receptionist and they are not saving lives.  
It is very hard for the nurses to ever eat or get take a break.  The economy and new health law seems to have frightened them into tightening their belts.  
Now with nursing jobs in low demand in this area, they will only hire BSN prepared nurses and want everyone to go back to school, although they will not pay for it.
cons: Poor raises, no loyalty, cutting staff, no support

review_title: We believe in inspired care...it's really true!
job_title: Pharmacist in Springfield, IL
pros: I've worked at St. John's for the past several years..and there has never been a day that isn't challenging. Some people may consider that a con, but I consider it a pro. I want to always be challenged and  I want to continue to learn, I believe that is the only way to continue to develop professionally. My team recognizes  my abilities and what I can bring to the table, it's comforting knowing that we always want to strive to do our job the best we can, and St. John's really encourages that. They really do believe in Inspired Care..not just for their patients but for their colleagues as well.
cons: Working in a hospital setting is always challenging, it's a lot different than working in a regular pharmacy. You have the challenge of working with physicians, residencies and other hospital staff on a daily basis. Thinking quick on your feet is a must in cases of emergency or trauma.

job_title: Switchboard Operator in Eau Claire, WI
pros:
-I got to do whatever I wanted: watch Netflix, go on Facebook, surf the web during my shift.
-PTO acquires quickly.
-Job was easy.
-They did whatever they could to get you the days off you need.
cons:
-Impossible to call in if you are sick or a death of a family member.
-If the next shift doesn’t show, you are stuck pulling a double.
-Have to cover lots of extra shifts due to vacation time.
-Work lots of weekends
-No breaks at all, can’t leave the office.
-You have to wait for someone to cover your office if you need to use the bathroom.
-Doctors yell at you when they don’t get their way.
- 0-3% raise every year with no room for negotiation.

job_title: CNA in Streator, IL
pros: There are no good experiences at all.  Cant even say the food in the cafeteria was good  because it was over priced and it was awful!!! And everyone just sat around talking about how miserable their jobs were.
cons: Management is so dishonest.  They will lie against you to save their jobs.  I have never seen so many greed and dishonesty and so called religious people in my life,  Their is so much fraud going on there.  I cannot believe the state passes them.  There are so many corners cut.  I can only pray more people do not die in their hands.

job_title: ICU Registered Nurse in Springfield, IL
pros: Due to being in the ICU, you learn a great foundation and skills from physicians and senior nursing staff. The spiritual staff at HSHS are by far the most compassionate and hard working sisters, chaplains, etc. that I have worked with.
cons: Pay was average at $22-25/hour. ICU nurses are expected to take 3 patient to 1 nurse ratios (all ICU status patients). This is asking for a patient neglect or abuse issue. So many new graduates coming in, that patient safety errors were continuing to happen without management fixing the issues.

review_title: A nepotistic view of a good organization GOING bad!
job_title: Client Service Specialist in Springfield, IL
pros:
Excellent culture and core values that transcend to all parts of life.
Fair pay for locations
Possible advancement (opportunities are available but MANAGERS choose who they want to elevate to the next level)
(Most) Employees are kind, care and understanding .
cons:
No one lives the core values (Respect, Care, Competence and Joy)
Too many manager and NO LEADERS!
Constant changes in standards
Lack of accountability at every level
Far too much favoritism in all departments
Opportunities are false positives

job_title: RN ICU in Springfield, IL
pros:
CoWorkers, teamwork. 
Technology is up to date/better versus other hospitals in the area. 
Schedule flexibility- overtime hours available.
Almost all MDs are pleasant to work with. 
Pay is competitive. 
GREAT nursing care!! Intelligent and professional nurses!
cons:
Upper management, too many changes that have made staff unhappy, and poor communication between upper management and staff. 
Need to focus on retention and not recruitment, LOTS of experienced nurses, but they're paying sign on bonuses to new employees who leave after a year and keep their old staff at the same rate of pay with no incentives. 
Too much cost cutting without paying attention to the effect on the staff.

job_title: Cashier In Fiscal Services in Eau Claire, WI
pros: Good Benefits, Work ethics lived by Christian Values of Care, Joy, Respect, and Competence
cons: Unfair way of determining an employee's worth. I was relieved of job duties after being a "go to" person for 38 years.

job_title: Speech Language Pathologist in Chippewa Falls, WI
pros: Wonderful, professional employees that truely cared about providing care and were making the hospital a profit.
cons: Servant attitude that originated and began the journey is changing. A not for profit entity cannot have the same attitude about making a profit and keep the caring, selfless mind-set. Employees no longer feel a part of a family and just another cog in the wheel to make money. Local hospital is losing or letting go wonderful caring employees and is not the wonderful place to work for as was the case 6 or so years ago.

review_title: Its not the worst company to work for.
job_title: Food and Nutrition in Belleville, IL
pros: The benefits are okay for PT employees but a lot cheaper for FT employees. You have to work a min of 32 hours a pay period to qualify for benefits. Time and a half is paid for certain holidays and you earn PTO. Its a religious nonprofit hospital. It has good values.
cons:
Small hospital and old
Sometimes is short staff
Lower paying
Raises have a lot to do with the number of hospital meetings you attend, they count as "points"

job_title: Registered Nurse in Springfield, IL
pros: Supportive coworkers, invaluable medical experience, working with state of the art medical equipment.
cons: Not cared about by administration. Poor staff ratios.

job_title: Medical Laboratory Scientist in Springfield, IL
pros: Laboratory full long term.employees with a large reservoir of knowledge and experience. Central stockroom supplied by housekeeping, meaning supplies were always available.
cons: District lack of regard for employees be the executive level management. Positions would not be replaced in the event of retirement leaving a ever shrinking workforce to cope with a growing workload. Staff shortages result in an over reliance of perdiem staff to fill in the gaps.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Oconto Falls, WI
pros: You learn a lot a medicine, pharmacology and the current procedures preformed on patients.  You get to know the Hospitalists and co-workers.  Most nurses and CNA work very well together and learn from each other. The management is kind, understanding and knowledgeable.
cons: This is a very small hospital and are often put on LOW CENSUS.  There is no limit to how many times/hours you are "called off" in a pay period.  If you don't have PTO saved you're often not getting paid.

job_title: Nurse Technician in Decatur, IL
pros: It has good staff and a good atmosphere, they do good about trying to keep the colleagues engaged in the work environment. Some of the educational leaders are awesome.
cons: A lot of the upper management is not very good and loves to play favorites. It can be very hard to work there and the burn out rate is super high because of it.

review_title: Overall a great place to work
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Belleville, IL

cons: Work load can be a bit heavier on some days but never too overwhelming because each team helps each other.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in O'Fallon, IL
pros: Good work culture, non for profit, really helps patients who may not have the financials for care, benefits are good
cons: Pay is only ok, furloughed lots of staff for covid, terminated positions of managers who had been there 25 plus years, seems like they have no loyalty to their staff. I was only there 6 months so I understand my termination. I just can't imagine letting go of very experienced and loyal employees

review_title: A Good Experience, but glad when it was finished.

cons: Pay scale was lower than their closest competitor, and there wasn't much in the way of well rounded training at the time. I hear this has improved.

review_title: Trying to be fair and honest.
job_title: Respiratory Therapist in Belleville, IL
pros: Steady paycheck until I find a better place.
cons: The second worst place I've ever worked. Lots of cancellations during summer overloaded with work in the winter. Staffed with under skilled personnel.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Sheboygan, WI
pros:
excellent employees
family atmosphere within most deparments
cons:
management turnover every 2-3 years over the last 6 years leaves most employees concerned for the lack of problem solving as each new leadership regime seems to put the staff through the same roller coaster ride of 'honeymoon phase' then 'indifference' .
* Current management is doing better than most and we pray that they stick around.

job_title: Client Service Specialist (IT) in Springfield, IL

cons: It takes time to move up the chain, but if you work hard. is is possible. There are always new positions opening up

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Springfield, IL
pros: I enjoyed my co-workers and some of the team building activities.
cons: It seemed like management was always searching for the next great program to turn around their poor financial performance - Lean, Six Sigma, Baptist Health, Disney, etc.  Felt like upper management was always concerned about their job security and attempted to micro-manage department directors.

job_title: Administrative Assistant
pros: Sisters and the colleagues I worked with daily.
cons: Management is horrible. Executives have a desire to be catered to 24/7. Unrealistic expectations. Tied to desk. Many days it was hard to just get time to go to the bathroom. No advocate for non-exempt employees when you have an issue to discuss. HR always sides w the manager, regardless of the issue, which is really not helping with HSHS growing a transparent work environment for colleagues.

review_title: A few leaders with overactive egos cause a lot of damage
job_title: Technical Analyst in De Pere, WI
pros: There are good people who work at that organization and add genuine social product; helping people grow while servicing the sick in our communities. Simply by being in their proximity of their sheer goodness, you find yourself bettered and inspired to better others. The best of them elevate you, show you a path of growth, and walk down that path with you for a little while, ensuring that you've found your footing.
cons:
There are select individuals in integral roles. These people adhere -- to almost no degree -- to the HSHS core values of Respect, Care, Competence, and Joy. They would be shamefully defenceless against the claim that they do not treat people with an inherent dignity, much less respect. They hear non-existent malice in benign criticism. Criticism so whimsical that surely you'd think that I'm being hyperbolic if you heard it in its entirety. They lash out defensively, inappropriately, with impunity like a school yard bully; delusional yet confident in their criticisms, making accusations of unprofessionalism while name-calling in the same sentence.* I often found myself affording them conversational honesty on simple decency, empty handed as the recipient of such, and all the more disadvantaged for it as they attack the semantics of any misstep. Their thought framework allows them to speak with blatant condescension while simultaneously claiming a bizarre kind of moral high ground. They are highly skilled, very intelligent assets, but I have accumulated alarmingly little reason to believe that they are *good* people. There are exceedingly few individuals such as this, but they function as a bottleneck within the organization; sludge in the headwaters.

Additionally, pay is not competitive at all. They get away with this by calling ALL I.T. positions "analysts" although they have much more appropriate role names (eg, Server Administrator, Application Developer...)

* Thankfully I preemptively recorded all private conversations knowing full well that I may need to validate any accusations of harassment, or defend myself against fabrications.

review_title: Like a prison no raises no lunches  horrible place
